title: 5.6×50mm Magnum
text:
The 5.6×50mm Magnum (designated as the 5,6 × 50 Mag. by the <a href="C.I.P.">C.I.P.</a>) is a centerfire, <a href="Rim%20%28firearms%29">rimless</a>, bottlenecked <a href="rifle">rifle</a> <a href="Cartridge%20%28firearms%29">cartridge</a> that was developed in 1970 by Günter Frères of the <a href="Deutsche%20Waffen%20und%20Munitionsfabriken">Deutsche Waffen und Munitionsfabriken</a> (DWM).
Parent case 5.6×50mmR Magnum.
In 1968 Günter Frères of the Deutsche Waffen und Munitionsfabriken (DWM) had developed the parent case the rimmed 5.6×50mmR Magnum (designated as the 5,6 x 50 R Mag. by the C.I.P.).
According to the official <a href="C.I.P.">C.I.P.</a> (Commission Internationale Permanente pour l'Epreuve des Armes à Feu Portatives) rulings the rimmed 5.6×50mmR Magnum can handle up to Pmax piezo pressure. That is less Pmax piezo pressure than the rimless 5.6×50mm Magnum.
Uses.
The 5.6×50mm Magnum and 5.6×50mmR Magnum cartridges were developed in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> as legal hunting cartridges for small game, <a href="fox">fox</a>, <a href="chamois">chamois</a> and <a href="roe%20deer">roe deer</a> at ranges up to and over . In North America it is considered a <a href="varmint%20hunting">varmint hunting</a> cartridge.
Related cartridges.
This cartridge occupies a useful performance niche approximately halfway between the <a href=".222%20Remington">.222 Remington</a> and the <a href="5.6%C3%9757mm">5.6×57mm</a>, similar to the slightly less powerful <a href=".222%20Remington%20Magnum">.222 Remington Magnum</a> and the <a href=".223%20Remington">.223 Remington</a>.
